serviceName: Get help finding a child arrangement option
printableVersion: View a printable version of the whole guide
phaseBannerText: This is a new service – your feedback will help us to improve it.

domesticAbuse.title: Domestic abuse
domesticAbuse.heading: Have you or your children experienced abuse from your ex-partner?
domesticAbuse.intro: You may have been in an abusive relationship if you or your children have experienced any of the following:

bullets.violence: Abuse or violence, including physical, emotional and sexual
bullets.coercive: Coercive control (threats, humiliation, intimidation, degradation, isolation and control)
bullets.childAbuse: Child abuse, neglect, or child abduction

domesticAbuse.error: Select whether you or your children have experienced abuse from your ex-partner

start.title: Get help finding a child arrangement option
start.description: Use this service to find out about your options for making child arrangements if you are a parent separating from your child's other parent.

content.circumstances: You will be asked questions about your circumstances, including your current relationship with your ex-partner.
content.personalDetails: You will not be asked for any personal details and your answers will not be saved or shared with anyone.
content.tenMinutes: It takes about 10 minutes to use this service.

exitTheService.title: If you need to exit the service quickly
exitTheService.description: Each page of this service has an 'Exit this page' button to help keep you safe and protect your privacy if you need it.

content.makingChildArrangements: Making child arrangements if you divorce or separate

content.howToStart: If you are unsure how you can start making child arrangements with your ex-partner, you can get help.

ifYouNeedHelp.title: If you need help deciding how to make child arrangements
ifYouNeedHelp.content: Use the 'Get help finding a child arrangement option' service to find out about your options for making child arrangements if you are a parent separating from your child's other parent.

howItWorks.title: How it works
howItWorks.content:
You will be asked questions about your circumstances, including your current relationship with your ex-partner. You will not be asked for any personal details.

It takes about 10 minutes to use this service.

exitTheService.title: If you need to exit the service quickly
exitTheService.content: Each page of this service has an 'Exit this page' button to help keep you safe and protect your privacy if you need it.

getHelpChildArrangementOption.title: Get help finding a child arrangement option
getHelpChildArrangementOption.content: Your answers will not be saved or shared with anyone.

supportWhenMakingChildArrangements.title: If you need support when making child arrangements
supportWhenMakingChildArrangements.content:
Search for services to help you make child arrangements, including legal aid and impartial advice services.

Find child arrangement support services

contactChildArrangements.title: Are you comfortable contacting your ex-partner about child arrangements?

options.second: No, I am not comfortable contacting them
options.third: No, I do not have their contact details
options.fourth: I can contact them but they do not respond

contactChildArrangements.error: Select whether you are comfortable contacting your ex-partner

agreement.title: Do you and your ex-partner agree on child arrangements?

descriptionList.second: when they spend time with each parent
descriptionList.third: handovers, holidays and whatever else matters to your children

options.first: Yes, we agree on some or most things
options.third: We have not discussed it yet

agreement.error: Select whether you and your ex-partner agree on child arrangements

helpOptions.title: What would help you both agree on child arrangements?

options.first: A plan we can follow ourselves
options.second: Someone else to guide our conversations
options.third: We cannot agree - someone else needs to make a decision for us

content.description: Have you tried any of the following together in the last 6 months?

options.yes: Yes, we have tried one or more of these
options.no: No, we have not tried any of these

optionsNoContact.title: Options to explore if you are not comfortable contacting your ex-partner

content.notComfortable: If you are not comfortable contacting your ex-partner, there are still ways you can make child arrangements without going to court.
content.solicitorCanContact: With these options, your mediator or solicitor can contact your ex-partner for you.

content.attendSession: Shuttle mediation is where you and your ex-partner both attend a session with a mediator, but sit in different rooms or online meetings so you do not have to have any contact.
content.mediatorMoves: The mediator moves between rooms, listening to you both and helping you come to an agreement about child arrangements.
content.getVoucher: You can usually get a voucher worth up to £500 to pay for family mediation through the Family Mediation Voucher Scheme, regardless of what you earn.
content.nextStep: Next step: Find out more about mediation

content.legalAdviser: A family legal adviser can help you negotiate with your ex-partner without going to court. This is known as 'solicitor negotiation' or 'lawyer negotiation'.
content.speakToExPartner: You do not have to speak to your ex-partner if you choose a solicitor to negotiate for you.
content.nextStep: Next step: Find a legal adviser from the Law Society

content.hireLegalAdviser: You and your ex-partner can each hire your own legal advisers to help you negotiate. You then all meet to try and agree on child arrangements.
content.nextStep: Next step: Find out more about collaborative law from Resolution

otherWaysToAgree.title: Other ways to agree without going to court
otherWaysToAgree.description: If you want to try another way to agree without going to court, you can look into:

content.arbitrationText: This could suit you if: You'd prefer that someone like a judge or solicitor listens to both of your views and makes a legally-binding decision about the child arrangements.
content.arbitrationLink: Find out more about other ways to agree without going to court

content.description: These are some of the services you may find helpful for making child arrangements.
content.mediationCouncilText: Find a trained mediator from a network of family mediation organisations in England and Wales.
content.citizensAdviceText: Advice on what to do if your child arrangements aren't working  from a network of independent charities that provides free, confidential and impartial advice online, on the phone and in person.

content.makingChildArrangements: Making child arrangements if you divorce or separate

cookies.title: Cookies
cookies.name: Name
cookies.aboutCookies:
Propose a child arrangements plan puts small files (known as ‘cookies’) onto your computer to collect information about how you browse the service.

Cookies are used to:

  • remember your progress
  • measure how you use the service so it can be updated and improved based on your needs

Propose a child arrangements plan cookies aren't used to identify you personally.

You'll normally see a message before we store a cookie on your computer.

Find out more about how to manage cookies.
cookies.howCookiesAreUsed: How cookies are used in this service
cookies.essentialCookiesUse: Essential cookies are needed for the service to work. We do not need to ask for permission to use them.
cookies.rememberingProgress:
Remembering your progress

We will store cookies to remember your application progress in this computer and to expire your session after 120 minutes of inactivity or when you close your browser.
cookies.sessionPurpose: Saves your current progress in this computer and tracks inactivity periods
cookies.sessionExpiry: After 120 minutes of inactivity or when you close your browser
cookies.cookiesMessage:
Cookies message

You may see a banner when you visit Propose a child arrangements plan inviting you to accept or reject optional cookies. We’ll set a cookies so that your computer knows you’ve seen it and not to show it again, and also to store your settings.
cookies.aboutOptionalCookies:
Measuring service usage (Google Analytics)

We use Google Analytics software to collect information about how you use Propose a child arrangements plan. We do this to help make sure the service is meeting the needs of its users and to help us make improvements

Google Analytics stores information about:

  • the pages you visit
  • how long you spend on each page
  • how you got to the service
  • what you click on while you’re visiting the service

We don't collect or store your personal information (for example your name or address) so this information can't be used to identify who you are.

Google Analytics sets the following cookies:
cookies.acceptOptionalCookies: Do you want to accept analytics cookies?
cookies._gaCookiePurpose: Checks if you’ve visited the service before. This helps us count how many people visit our site.
cookies._ga_IdCookiePurpose: Used by Google Analytics to find and track an individual session with your device.

notFound.title: Page not found
notFound.check: Please check the web address is correct.

generic.title: Sorry, there is a problem with the service
generic.tryReloading: You can try reloading the page or start again.

rateLimit.title: Too many requests have been made
rateLimit.info: The page has been reloaded too many times in a short period.
rateLimit.tryReloading: Please wait a period of 15 minutes, then try reloading the page or start again.

cookieBanner.title: Cookies on Get help finding a child arrangement option
cookieBanner.useEssentialCookies: We use some essential cookies to make this service work.
cookieBanner.useAnalyticsCookies: We’d also like to use analytics cookies so we can understand how you use the service and make improvements.
cookieBanner.acceptedAnalyticsCookies: You’ve accepted analytics cookies. You can change your cookie settings at any time.
cookieBanner.rejectedAnalyticsCookies: You’ve rejected analytics cookies. You can change your cookie settings at any time.
